nodes.text: Before we get started, I want to remind you all that the Midterm Exam will be held in three days, so I suggest you study for it.
Today, we will discuss the philosophical differences between Rogues and Thieves.

Thieves, by their actions and their nature, are essentially self-centered and callous towards their victims. As long as they benefit in the end, they have little or no concern who they hurt to attain their goal.
For example, Herr O'Conner took a book from the Locker room without permission and failed to return it. He violated a Rogue Rule with this theft. Therefore, he is clearly a thief.
As a result, he failed to pass the last test.

Thieves are notoriously short-sighted and seldom think about the negative consequences of their actions. Rogues should always consider the repercussions before removing things they were expressedly told not to take.
Is that not right, Herr O'Conner?
Yes, sir.
Thieves' Guilds are like wolf packs - the strongest, smartest, and most ruthless becomes the Chief Thief.
'There is no honor amongst thieves' is a truism. Even in a guild, you have to watch your back. If someone sees a weakness in another thief, he will take advantage of him.
This is not to say that all Thieves are inherently wicked. There are a few honorable people who consider themselves to be Thieves. However, they are actually Rogues.

Rogues develop strong friendships with people they can trust. They know that life can be unfair, so they do what they can to make the world a little fairer. They try not to harm the innocent, but they have few qualms when dealing with the guilty.
Rogues use many of the same tools and skills as Thieves. Rogues break laws, break into houses, steal things, cheat, lie, and swindle. How then, are we any better than they?
Herr Kent?
Rogues do things for a noble cause?
Perhaps for a given definition of the word 'noble', you are correct. Nobility is always a matter of interpretation. However, Rogues do have an innate sense of morality.
Let us see if you can draw a line between the acts of a Thief and the acts of a Rogue.
A man goes around a country marketplace filching money pouches at any opportunity. Is he a Thief or a Rogue and why?
The man is clearly a common thief since he's pilfering purses from people who have little wealth of their own.
Indeed.
Another example: a masked woman sneaks into a mansion during a masquerade and flirts with the other people there while she steals a valuable piece of jewelry.
Is she a Thief or a Rogue, Herr Kyro?
She is a Rogue because she is using trickery to steal from the rich?
What is your opinion on this matter, Fräulein MacMichael?
I don't know what she is. It depends on why she is stealing and what she does with it afterwards.
Precisely. If I added that this mysterious woman then returned the stolen jewelry to its original owner, only then can we judge whether she is a Rogue or not.
Whenever you do a roguish act, you must ask yourself - who does it hurt? Who does it help? What are the consequences of my actions? Is the world better because of what I do?

Rogues can be heroes, but we won't be the ones awarded medals for acts of valor. We do things behind the scenes, manipulate the players, and let someone else be targeted as the hero of the day. We work best from the shadows.
So, Fräulein Esme, what would you do as a Rogue?

I vould dress up as Fortune Teller and read people's palms. I vould say to bad man that the ghosts of his victims vill drag him to Hades on the Nights of the Dead unless he repaid his debts before the next full moon.
A fine ploy.
Herr O'Conner - what Roguish thing could you do?

I'd make friends with the minion of a corrupt politician. I'd invite the minion to a tavern where I'd buy drinks and get him to tell me all the politician's dirty secrets. Then I'd break into the politician's house, steal incriminating evidence, and give that evidence to all the newspapers around town.
Interesting approach, if slightly conventional.
Say that there is this greedy, stingy old businessman in town who is rich. I'd dress up as a ghost, break into his house in the middle of the night, and pretend to be his dead partner.

I'd warn him that he'd be dead in a year's time unmourned and unloved unless he repented from his greed and treated those around him with kindness. Then I'd haunt him again for three more nights until he changed his ways.
And if he didn't change his ways in three days' time, I'd rob his safe and secretly leave the money with all his workers.
You have an interesting imagination, Herr O'Conner. Perhaps you should become a novelist rather than Rogue.
So there are these two men who despise one another. I'd go to each of them secretly and agree to get them to pay me to bring them incriminating evidence against the other one.
So what happens when the two men find out that you are working against them both?
Don't worry, I'll be long gone before they find out.
Tomorrow's lesson will be on advanced trap detection. You will find the Trap Tapper disarm tool and the Houdini 42 Advanced Lockpick on sale in the store.
With the Trap Tapper, you will be able to disarm traps set upon locks to prevent lockpicking. You will need one for tomorrow's lesson.
Schluss!
